values:
I'd taken the train out to California.  It was a nice ride.  Long, but nice.  As much as I'd like to say that I'd come out here for a social visit, there is some Council business I'm out here on.  I may have taken a couple extra days of my own.  Do you know when the last time I took a vacation was?

Yeah, neither do I.

That's probably why Murphy laughed her ass off when I told her and asked her watch Mister and Mouse for me.  

Admittedly, it's not much of a vacation.  It's a couple of days.  However, I am out here to look up a good friend.  At least, I assume he's still a good friend.  I've developed a bad habit of not staying in touch as well as I should.  I'm assuming he'll be forgiving.

I guess I'll find out in a few minutes.  The cab's pulling up at the address I have for the restaurant his family runs.  I pay the fare and step onto the sidewalk.  Nice place.  And it smells amazing.

Meandering off this thread here: http://mago-sonriente.livejournal.com/796.html#comments

this is the last comment that's the same: http://mago-sonriente.livejournal.com/796.html?thread=72732#t72732

<lj-cut text="after this - things are different">

Still not enough coffee.  I refill my cup and drink the scalding liquid to stave off the blistering heat and what's left of the sleepiness in my brain.  Truth be told, it's not just sleep making me grouchy.  It's not just the attacks or the dead kids.  But talking about it won't help at all.  And taking it out on Ramirez won't help either.  

I fill the cup again and duck back into the tent with an apple.  It gives my hands something to do.  My mouth too.  If it's full of apple my foot won't fit.  I don't know what I'll say if he comes back in here.  Suppose I'll think of something.

</lj-cut>

I left Greg downstairs to brood over his birthday until he decides to come upstairs.

The loft is most of one floor of a building in Mid-town Chicago.  It's open and airy and would be considered a one-room apartment except that I added what appears to be a darkroom to one end.  That's actually my lab - where I do my wizard research.  It's where I kept Bob until it got too sketchy to leave him here alone.

The bed's on the opposite wall from the 'lab' and the bathroom's between the two.  Kitchen's across from those three with a living room space in the middle.

And - it's clean.  It actually looks a lot like I left it.  Which either means really neat burglars or no one's been here.

I'm hoping for that latter, honestly.

Previous!Other!Harry - he was afraid of eveyrthing... no, really, nearly everything. All b/c of Justin. I mean, the guy lost his family by the time he was 8, then was taken in by a child molester who taught through fear - 'do this (do this right) or you will be punished severely' - so he was afraid to screw up, afraid of 'being bad', but he was also, only really taught 'dark' magic. He never got that positive influence from McCoy, so he didn't know he had any other choice. Then, when he was sent to other!M'ways, he started to get some of it, but he was still VERY hesitant to let ppl in - since the only ppl who'd been let in before either were dead or had hurt him. He had SERIOUS trust issues and never WANTED anyone to get close, but those persistant bastards at the bar just HAD to make him take a look at things differently. Not that that's bad - he just wasn't mentally stable enough to handle it - it all came on a little too fast for his damaged psyche to handle. Especially once he discovered he actually knew how to love someone - that scared the hell out of him, b/c he always had that fear that Justin was right there waiting to punish him for doing something he wasn't supposed to be doing. More than that though, he was afraid of being alone - so when he then fell in love with Bethany, he didn't want to give up David, b/c he was afraid of being left alone if one or the other decided they didn't want him anymore. He thought he needed a 'back-up' - even after he told David they couldn't be together anymore. And he really tried to make the relationship with Bethany work, but when it got rocky - he didn't know what to do. He honestly never expected Bethany to dump him after one mistake, that he didn't feel was entirely his fault. He just didn't understand how the relationship was supposed to work. His only knowledge of romantic relationships came from the books he read - and ppl in those made mistakes all the time, but still go to keep the relationship - it was all he knew and it really upset him that instead of teaching him, she left him to try to figure it out on his own - and he just couldn't do it.
I usher him inside and yell for Bob to help me with healing spells.

A few more of these weird memories have come back.  I have this idea that I know what's going on, but I'm still not sure.  I know they're mine - the memories - but I don't know why I'm getting them now.

There was that thing with Stephen the other day and now this.  Something about a cave in the coldest, farthest part of the bar.  I don't know exactly what that means, but I suppose I should find out.

I figure if I don't, I'll just have a huge headache and no answers.

Just one thing though - I don't want to wander around here by myself.  

I crawl into the bed where there is a rather attractive, unshaven, sleeping man and lean down to nibble on his neck.  "Greg," I say with almost a sing-song tone.  "Wake up, Greg."  

I want him to come along for the ride.

There are layers - 

the first is faded, very faded, it's the life that was - who Harry was before he left to come back as that snarky seven-year-old boy.  It's hard to see, but still there - all of the things he still has to deal with that will be more visible later.

the next is the boy who loves his father.  (This is the boy Greg first met.)  He loves his dad and loves helping him, working with him.  He's a happy child, living a happy life.

then there's the orphan.  His life is hard, but despite all of what he has to go through, he's still a relatively happy child.  His life is frustrating, but instead of burying his head in the sand, he presses on, proving to everyone who doubts him that he can do whatever he wants, be whatever he wants to be, no matter what they say or do.

and there's the magician, the stage performer, the professional.  It's hard work, but he loves it.  He makes people smile, makes them happy and that's important.  It reminds him of his dad.  There are the twinges of pain from the relationship woes, but most of the pieces around Jeffrey are happy too.  In here, there is also the warm feelings from the relationship with Greg.  Greg makes him feel safe, makes him happy.

finally, the wizard.  The most recent layer, thus the most vivid.  This is who he is.  He's a wizard and he's powerful.  More powerful than even he knows yet and he's got a decent control on the power he does have.  There's the shadow of Justin's death, but even that is clouded over by the confidence.  Harry knows he can handle himself in a fight and he knows his magic will work and that he has friends on the Council who will back him.  That confidence is what wasn't there before - it won't be seen in that faded layer.

It Sparks... I'm trying to make this work again. I did it on stage last night, completely by accident, and it looked awesome. Naturally, I want to incorporate it into my act. I just have to figure out what I did. It's just a simple destruction trick - I take a rose and make it disappear, only this time, it didn't just go *poof*, it went up in flames, only the sleight of hand part worked too, so I still had the rose to bring it back a bit later. (Shut up, everyone knows how that trick works anyway.) As I'm working, I either get the sleight of I burn the rose. Dammit. "You're thinking too much, Dresden. Concentrate less on the fire and more on the timing," Morgan instructs as he enters the room. This requires a little explanation. Remember when I got stinking drunk for a month or so a little while back? Morgan was mightily pissed at all of the sessions I missed. (Alexandrov was angry about the shows I missed, but missing performances hurt me more than it hurt him, in the long run.) I still wanted to work on the magic and Morgan put me through hell as a harsh reminder of how valuable his time is. His and mine. It was a rough couple of months and I had to work every day. My stage gigs suffered a bit - again, that was my fault. We're back on track now and Morgan doesn't hate me. "...more on the timing," he was saying. "Right." He's told me that before. I shift my concentration and try again. No dice - still burnt the damned rose. "Dresden, clear your mind, focus. You know how to make the fire and you know how to vanish the rose. Delicate shifts of your mind will synchronize the two..." his voice is a smooth mantra that helps me focus. He's a jackass, but he knows his stuff. The trick works - a perfect balance of fire and sleight of hand. Not I just have to practice the hell out of it until I can do it without thinking. I'll get there. ******** It Never Heats... I'm sitting in the coffee shop, reading the new X-Men, having my coffee, when a pretty blonde approaches me and asks if she can share my table. The shop is a little crowded and there are other tables, but I give her a nod with a smile and let her hit. "Hi," I say, sort of still reading my comic. She smiles back and asks, "Haven't I seen you somewhere?" I assume she means she's seen me on stage, but the evil negative side of my subconscious thinks she saw me one of those nights when I was smashed and is ready to pummel me for doing something chauvinistic. Let's not go there. "Probably," I reply - still reading. She said she wanted to share my table, not my life story. Her smile doesn't falter. "If I'm bothering you, I'll go." I look up again. "No. You're fine." "I'm Lisa," And she holds out her hand to me. I try not to sigh as I meet her hand and respond with, "Harry." I'm trying to read here. "Ooh! Like the magician!" At that, I just arch an eyebrow. This girl is nuts. "Houdini?" she says, bordering on Valley Girl. Oh hell. "You know, daring escapes and such." Christ, why can't anything ever be simple? "Yeah," I respond, "something like that." She just keeps smiling at me and sipping her coffee. I peer up at her from my comic. "You're not going to leave until I talk to you, are you?" "Hm? OH, no, I just think you're interesting. Very animated when you read." She taps my comic with a slender finger. "Must be good." Better when you're not putting your greasy, coffee-wet fingers on it. "It is." I try very hard not to growl. Her digits are trying to ruin my book. Lisa sighs and nibbles on her lip and I feel my shoulders stiffen, bracing for impact. "I'm just gonna do this or I'll talk myself out of it." Here it comes. "Would you like to go out to dinner with me?" May-day! May-day! We're going in! I told you. I fight the urge to slam my head against the table. I put on my best stage smile and reply, "I'm flattered. Thank you. But I'm not in place, right now, to get into a relationship." The nights spent curled up with Greg not-withstanding, I'm not ready yet. Lisa laughs. "I'm not asking you to move in with me. I just wanted to share a meal with you." She sips her coffee again. "It's just one date." I sigh, not relenting. "I'm sorry. I just can't right now." Memories of Jeffrey surface and it's difficult to shove them aside. Apparently she saw something in my face that sparked an emotional reaction in herself, because she suddenly shifted from insistently asking me out, to looking like she wanted to hug me. "I'm so sorry. I had no idea." "It's okay," I tell her. Though maybe it's not. Greg's one thing - I've known him since I was seven, but a random person on the street? I just can't do it. She looks a little uncomfortable, like she's not sure what to do now. Join the club, dear. She sips her coffee and pushes her hair back from her face, revealing hazel eyes, mostly green. "Can I give you my number and if you ever change your mind, you can give me a call?" I was going to say 'no' until I glanced up and caught her eye. In that moment something happened that had never happened before - our gazes locked and wouldn't let go. But there's more. When I looked in her eyes, I saw something. I think it was her - inside her - but it was weird. Scared the hell out of me. I hear a gasp from across the table as the thing ends and I ask if she's all right. "What the hell was that?" she whispers, a bit frightened herself I'd expect. "I don't know." "What? How could you not know?" "It's never happened before." "What the hell did you just do to me? And who is Margaret?" My head snaps up again. "What? How do you know about that?" "It's what she said. Her name was Margaret." Lisa puts a hand to her head and rubs her temple. "That hurt, but who is she?" My voice is so quiet I almost can't hear myself. "My mother." Lisa blinks. "Oh, I'm sorry." And I feel her lay her hand on mine. "What'd she say?" Lisa shrugs. "Nothing really. Just that her name is Margaret and something about family." I swallow - hard. Family. The one thing I've always wanted; the one thing I've never had. What did she mean by that? I blink at fingers suddenly waving in front of my eyes. "Hey, Harry, you still in there?" "Yeah. Fine." "So, what'd you see, or am I completely empty?" A slight shake of my head. "No. Not empty, but undeveloped power lives beneath the surface." "What kind of power?" She sounds intrigued. I shrug. "You got me. That's all I saw." Which is only half true. There was more, but I'm gonna keep that to myself. "Huh." She seems really okay with all this. "So, did you want my number? You know, just in case you want someone to talk to?" "Sure, thanks." I nod as I get up from my chair. "Wait, where are you going?" She rests a hand on my arm and I can feel a soft energy from it now. I glance down at her hand, then back to her eyes. "I'm late for an appointment. I've got to go." "Sure. Call me though. Really." "Yeah. Maybe." And I leave the coffee shop before she tempts me with anything else. My mind is reeling as I walk. I don't know where I'm going, but it doesn't really matter. I need to think. She saw - she saw my mother and my mother said something about family. What the hell does that mean? And why didn't Morgan tell me about that eye thing? Though, I'm thinking I shouldn't do that anymore. ******** I've spent the last couple days debating with myself on telling Morgan about what happened with Lisa. Problem is, I'm no closer to a decision now than I was then. On the one hand, I want to tell him and find out what that was, but on the other, I don't want to talk to Morgan about my mother. I think it's time to talk to her again. I haven't been here since before Jeffrey left and I'm a little ashamed of that. Hi Mom - Dad... Don't know if you remember Jeffrey or not, but he's gone now. He went on to tour in Europe. I'm afraid I didn't take that very well and it took going to the end of the universe and back to realize that self-destructing almost killed me. I'm over that now. There's someone else though. Not like that, just someone I've been meaning to tell you about, but kind of liked keeping to myself. His name is Greg and he sort of stepped in as a father figure after Dad died. I don't know why it was him, but he was there when I needed someone and he's been there every time I've gone back. Er, yeah, I should probably mention that this is at the end of the universe at that bar. But, anyway, he's always there and he never tells me to go away and he's helped me more than I can express. I don't know that I would've survived some of the things I have without him. Not that he's the only one there who's helped me; he just seems to stand out more than the others. I like spending time with him. Like, before I came back to Chicago, we sat together on the couch in my suite - don't ask - and neither of us said a word. We just sat there and I fell asleep and it was one of the best nights I've spent with anyone. No pressures, no demands, just us and it works. I miss him too. He's a big part of why I hope I can go back. I'm doing the best I can with my life and I hope it's enough. I've gotta go now. Work to do. I miss you both. I blink tears from my eyes and realize, when I glance down, that I've been holding the Duncan yo-yo I snagged from Greg's room before I left. I've played with it a few times - even tried to find a way to work it into my act (that didn't go over too well) - but mostly, I just look at it and remember. Happy memories. I like those. ******** It Burns... Now that I'm back in the swing of things and have my life more-or-less in order, back to the stage I've gone. And last night one of the craziest things happened. I was on stage, setting up for my mid-show trick. My assistant called volunteers to the stage - just two - and asked their names for the audience to hear as I stepped forward, trick items in hand. The volunteers were getting ready for their part - holding the red silk like a shelf between them where I would place the item that was to disappear. Up until this point, I was paying little attention to the other people on the stage, as I needed to focus my concentration without looking disinterested. As I was beginning the trick, pattering to the audience, I caught sight of the male volunteer and tried to hide the sudden apprehension. I asked their names again - as I normally do - during the lead-up to the trick. The man said 'Justin' and the little flame that I normally would display, turned into a huge ball of fire that lashed at Justin and the female volunteer at my other side. When I looked up, Justin was nearly engulfed in flames and flailing. As much as I wanted to leave him to burn - fear again - I grabbed him and threw him to the floor, rolling him over and over to put out the flames. Someone had called EMS, because I heard screaming sirens, then a bustle of medical personnel on the stage. Justin was howling - he had suffered more severe injuries than the other volunteer - but he was alive. They both were, as was my assistant, who suffered a few cuts and bruises, and myself. I, closest to the flames, suffered no injuries at all. As they wheeled the victims out of the theatre, I heard Justin wailing at me about how I planned this and was trying to kill him. That's just great. ******** "You're free to go, Mr. Dresden. We're very sorry for your trouble." Morgan and I collect our things and take out leave. We spent two hours with investigators. Alexandrov is on tour, so he doesn't know about any of this. Morgan was at the show, so he came along for the interrogation. He's not a lawyer, but he knows some things. I don't think the policy believed Justin anyway. But, just to be safe, Morgan helped me work up some enchanted items to use as wards and warnings, as well as some wards for my apartment. He won't tell me much, but he says Justin's 'bad news'. Same thing my dad told me. I don't know what the bastard wants with me and I don't want to find out. "Be careful, Dresden. DuMorne has sworn revenge," Morgan tells me. "What does that mean?" "Nothing good." Morgan faces me. "But you are strong, Dresden. You can face him and survive." I note that he says 'survive' and not 'win'. Thanks, Morgan.

It Never Rains... Back to Chicago, into the bar I was going to patronize when I found myself back at the end of the universe and who so I see? Oh no, not Jeffrey - I would've been pissed at that. No, worse - Justin. In all his blond-haired, boy-next-door creepiness. And do you know what the bastard has the balls to do? He offers to buy me a drink. "Get the hell out of my face, asshole!" I snarl at him and he just stands there, blinking at me in utter shock. He stutters something that sounds like 'but you were drunk,' which only serves to make me more angry, because him knowing that means he was following me. I don't like people following me. I don't push him. I don't hit him. I just glare and tell him, in no uncertain terms, that if he doesn't get away from me, the two nice gentlemen made of muscles and steel will be introducing his face to the pavement outside. That seems to be enough to get him to go away. As for me, I give the bartender a wave and turn around to exit the bar. No more drinking for me. Not for a while. ****** I'm still not sure how to explain things to Alexandrov and Morgan. I'll come up with something, though, I suppose. I've resigned myself to the fact that they're pretty much going to kill me.

[OOC: From the events played out here...] It was still dark when I got up, so I moved quietly, gathering my clothes and pulling them on, then slipping out into the dimly lit hallway. I glanced back at Greg, sleeping on the bed, for a moment, then pulled the door closed and walked away. I'm sitting in what appears to be the sitting room of a larger suite. I don't know how I found it, but I told the bar I needed a quiet place to sit. So, I'm sitting. The lights are off and my shoes are off and the nasty smells on me from yesterday are off. I had a shower and now I'm sitting - jeans and a T-shirt - and my hair dripping water onto my shoulders.

Decisions "So, you gonna do it?" Jeffrey asks me one night as we're working on a marathon battle of Space Invaders. "I don't know yet," I say off-hand, twisting to get a better handle on the controller. "Don't you have to decide by tomorrow?" "Yeah. I'll know by then." "What's the hold up?" "You." "Me? What? Why?" He's distracted enough by that that I take down his ship. Oops. I hit the button to pause the game and turn to face him. "Just a concern that I won't have enough time to spend with you if I do everything that I want to do." I'm able to hold eye contact, which is kind of good, right? He puts down the controller and presses his palm to my cheek, it's warm and gentle. "Harry, don't let me be the reason you don't do something you want to do. If you really want this, I won't stop you." "I have thought about it." I reach into a pocket and draw out the schedule that I made. "See." He takes the sheet of paper from me, studies it. "When did you do this?" "Coffee shop. Couple days ago." One of the few lies I've had to tell him, because I can't tell anyone about Milliways - they wouldn't believe me anyway. A smile lights his face when he looks up at me again. "I think this will do just fine, if you're serious about doing this 'wizard thing' - as you call it." "I'm still not sure." I'm being such a wimp about all this. "Do you want to do it? The wizard magic?" "Yes." That's easy. "Okay. Do you want to continue the stage magic?" "Yes." That's even easier. "So do 'em both. What do you have to lose?" He grins at me again. "You," I answer softly, scared. He laughs and pulls me into a hug, tumbling us back on the floor. "I'm not going anywhere, jerk." Then he kisses me and tries to tickle me, which results in an hour-long tickle fight.
Teachers Alexandrov worked us extra hard yesterday - probably because Jeffrey and I were sloppy the day before. Our fault entirely, because we stayed up waaaaaay too late doing things that were far more fun than sleeping. We're very bad boys. However, on the bright side, we have today off from rigorous training. Typically, this would mean lots of free time to do more fun things, but I'm heading into the city to meet my other teacher. I'll admit to being a bit apprehensive about this meeting. Mr. Howlett set it up, but he wasn't able to come along - said he had other things he needed to do - so I'm on my own, because I was told non-wizards couldn't come along. Yes, I had to leave Jeffrey behind to make his own fun. My teacher's name is D. Morgan. I don't know what the D stands for or how, exactly, I'm supposed to address him when I meet him. I guess I'll find out soon enough. I step off the train and walk the few blocks to the office building where I'm to meet Mr. D. Morgan. The front desk is lacking a secretarial person and the place looks abandoned, but I pressed the buzzer and was buzzed in, so I must be in the right place. "Mr. Dresden," a deep voice booms from the shadows and I nearly jump out of my skin. "Holy crap!" I turn around to see a man, nearly as tall as me, but heavier, bulkier. I'm sure he could take me out with sheer physical force if he had a mind too. I don't dare guess what he could do to me with whatever wizard powers he has. "You are late," he states without reaction to my outburst. "Not by any timepiece I own," I respond. I am not late. In fact, I'm twenty minutes early for this meeting. He scowls at me. Have you ever had a tall black man with graying brown hair who looks like he could crush you with a good hit scowl at you? If you can help it, don't. "No, Mr. Dresden, you are late finding your magic." "In all honesty, that wasn't my fault. My physical growth spurt was the dominant gene." "Stop talking." And somehow, I get the feeling that if he truly wanted to mute my voice, he could. "When you come to me for your lessons, you will be silent and speak only when spoken to, or acknowledged when you have a question." I can only stare at him in shock. I've known people to be direct, but this is almost strict. Remind me never to complain about Alexandrov again. His face is stern as he looks me over. No idea what he's looking for - scars, rash, evil, signs that I'm not one-hundred percent heterosexual. Find whatever you want, I'm not changing who I am for anyone. "You have not been asked to change anything, Mr. Dresden." He heard me? How the - ? "But you will be. In due time." I'm not sure I like this guy much, but I don't have much choice on this wizard teacher thing.
Lessons My first official lesson with Morgan - which is what he told me to call him - was, we'll say, interesting. It lasted six fucking hours and by the end, the only thing I knew was how to make a broom sweep on its own and that Morgan is a masochist. So now, I'm spending the next several hours in a very hot bath. No, I'm not too macho to admit that my muscles need the moist heat of a bath. Oh, did I forget the part where Jeffrey is sitting here with me; rubbing my tired muscles and kissing me. God I love him. "So, you gonna go back?" he asks, smoothing a hand over my chest. I shrug and wince - sore muscles everywhere. "Probably. I want to learn this. And as hard as the work was, it was kind of fun." "Good." He kisses my neck. Now I'm concerned. Something's up, something he's not telling me. "Jeffrey?" He rests his chin on my shoulder and sighs. He's nervous. Come on, Jeffrey, just talk to me. "I love you," he says, turning my head to kiss me. He's hiding something, but I'm too tired to think about it now. ****** "You are late," Morgan snaps at me as I enter the warehouse and drop my coat onto a chair. "Was visiting my mother," I reply, tired. He scowls in confusion. "Your mother is deceased." I scowl right back. "Doesn't mean I can't visit her." Bite me, asshole. "But it does mean that she will be there when you leave today." Morgan sets out several objects on a table. "Fuck you, Morgan. It's my mother's birthday." I'm not in the mood for shit like this today. Either he grows some compassion or I quit. His face is still dark, annoyed with me, I'm certain. "Magic requires discipline," he stops setting up and faces me, arms crossed over his chest. "If you do not have the required discipline, we will end today. Now." I sigh and try not to snarl. "I have more than enough of the required discipline. However, I also have dead parents that I need to spend time with even if it's not always convenient for you. If you don't have enough heart to allow me an extra fifteen minutes, then I don't want to be your student." He's smiling. The bastard is smiling. What the hell is this, the Twilight Zone? He bows his head to me and closes the distance between us. "Mr. Dresden, your tenacity and your devotion to your family will make you an exceptional wizard." He turns to walk back to the table and I hear him mutter, "If it doesn't get in your way." Bastard. ****** "Very nice," Jeffery comments on my hovering ball of fire. He's the only person who's not afraid to slide up close to me when I'm working. This time, he's even got his arms around me and his head on my shoulder. I release the force of will holding the fireball together and it fizzles into a cloud of smoke. "What's up?" I don't need encouragement. I've been working on this wizard stuff for the last six - almost seven - years. My concentration's good, my technique is nearly flawless and Morgan's stopped thinking I'm a smartassed kid. Even though, by wizard standards, I am still a kid. Morgan's over one hundred years old. No wonder he's such a smarmy bastard. The support is welcomed, really, but not when he's actually here to tell me something else. He's been with me the whole time, he should know by now that I pick up on things. I can sense when he's tense and I know when he wants to talk serious. This is one of those times. "I've been offered a travelling partnership tour," he tells me and licks the sensitive skin of my throat. After a moan, "How's that bad?" He shrugs. "It's not. For me. It's in Europe." And since I haven't been offered the same opportunity, the 'partner' in this equation isn't me. I can't leave anyway. I take that back, I actually could leave, travel to Europe and study with another teacher, but that's a lot of starting-over. Besides, if Jeffrey's going to be travelling, unless my wizard master travelled along with, the learning would be complex at best. Dammit. I hate it when my brain is rational. I nod and slide my hands against his. "When do you leave?" "Next week." "Damn, Jeffrey." "Hey, I've only known for a month. I've spent the last few weeks trying to decide if I was gonna go. It's an opportunity of a lifetime." He's smiling, which is great, but that doesn't make this any easier for me. I lower my head. "You're going to leave me, aren't you?" "I think it's best." He pulls on my shoulder, trying to turn me around, which I stubbornly resist. "Harry, look at me." I turn around, eyes dark, angry, hurt. "Harry, if there was a way... but it's not fair to you - or me - to keep this relationship as it is if we'll never see each other." I don't think I can handle this. Not now. "Why? We could - we could make it work." I want him to go, to do this tour, because it's amazing, but I don't want him to leave me. He shakes his head. "Maybe we could, but Harry, I don't want to tie you down like that. It's not fair to either of us. I love you and I know this hurts, but it's the best way." He sighs and closes his eyes and kisses me and I try to hate it, but I can't. "And, Harry," he says, lips still brushing mine, "don't wait for me. I don't know how long I'll be gone. Live your life. Love your life. It's a good one." One more kiss and he turns to go. He thinks I don't know, but I can hear him crying. Or maybe that's me.
Drinks Damn. Almost closin' time already an' I'm not ev'n drunk yet. Fuck it. Morgan's pissed at me for missing a lesson; Alexandrov's pissed at me for missing a show; I'm sure there are others - I just don't care right now. My boyfriend ditched me and fucked up m'life, so now I'm just gonna drink 'til I don' care anymore. And I'm no' there jus' yet. Unfortun'tly, they're kickin' me out o'the bar, so I gotta find somewhere else t'go. There's 'nother bar down th'street tha's still open...

[ooc: Harry fell asleep next to Holly...] [...and finds himself a little startled when he wakes up. The rabbits are back in their cage and he's curled up against something soft and warm and he's almost afraid to move...]

Bethany, Thank you. Thank you so very much for being just like him... yes, Justin. Thank you for making sure I had no second chance on this. It's not like I was ever given second chances before; don't know why I would expect them now. Maybe I believed Nick when he told me this place was different. Maybe I really thought something in my life was going to work out. Boy was I ever wrong on that one. Just like him... punishment for one mistake with not a chance to rectify. Thank you. Why did I think that anything at all would ever change in my life. I had four people who cared about me... and now I have none. I have nothing. And I tried... tried so hard to do this right... to do everything right. But, I'm only human and I make mistakes. If you can tell me that you've never made a mistake in your life, I'll gladly leave you be and never mention this again. But, I just don't understand how one mistake can do so much damage. This was so hard for me. Moving from, to simplify, 'no rules', to 'tight rules'. I'm not comfortable with rules quite that stringent - been there, done that, took me nearly 25 years to escape it. ((there's a long period where Harry writes nothing)) I'm supposed to get it right the first time? I've never done this before. I don't know exactly how it works. You wouldn't expect me to fly a plane the first time up, so why do you think that I could do this perfectly the first time? You didn't even give me a chane to figure out exactly what I did so it wouldn't happen again. I understand that what happened with David was bad, but I still don't understand why it happened. You didn't give me a chance to try to prove that I could do better. You just took the one mistake and assumed I could never change. Thank you. That really makes me feel better about myself. I spent my whole life being told I was useless as a person and a poor excuse for a wizard. Until the people here helped to change that - or, I thought they had. Turns out, I really am useless as a person and I'm a poor excuse for a wizard. Didn't figure it would be someone I loved proving that to me, but lessons come from everywhere. That's fine. At least now I know. As soon as I find a way, I'm going back to Chicago. Don't follow me. Don't try to stop me. You won't change my mind. I don't belong here. And I have no reason to stay. Tell Adam I'm sorry. i can't tell you now or ever again, but i do still love youHarry

After the nearly traumatizing drama of this morning and a bit more sleep - it's very nice to sleep curled up against another warm body - I wake up and find a very lovely woman curled up on my chest. I drop a kiss to her hair and stroke a hand up and down her back. I'll talk to Thomas later. Teach him a little decorum.

My apartment is in the basement of an old boarding house.  It's lit by candles and the smoldering embers of the fireplace.  That's how it's heated too.  The rooms are small, but comfortable.  

We end up standing right in the middle of the living room and I take Bob down to the lab before I stir up the coals in the fire.

"Did you want something to drink?" I ask as Mister shoulders my calves and tries his best to knock me over.

20 Things about (other)Harry on 24 December (because some of them could change at the drop of a hat): 1. He doesn't like peanut butter. 2. He thinks he's a complete failure. 3. He's cocky, arrogant, not confident; not remotely. The only thing he's ever confident about is his magic. 4. He misses the hell out of his dad. The fact that he's actually in the bar now doesn't change this. 5. He doesn't understand loving just one person at a time. Hell, he never uderstood loving anyone at all until David. Which may be why he has such a hard time giving him up and trying to work on something else. 6. He's afraid of being alone forever. He keeps to himself and tells himself he likes being alone better because that way no one hurts him, but he's afraid he won't have anyone there when the end comes; that no one will care. 7. He wishes he'd had a chance to know his mother. 8. Sometimes he wants to smack Thomas, but overall, he thinks he's okay. 9. He didn't really mind the head bartender gig. 10. He misses talking to Nick. A lot. 11. He doesn't know how he feels about Stephen. He wishes he did, but he's afraid to think about it too much because he likes having all of his appendages. 12. Michael is the one person he's really afraid of. Everyone else, he's pretty sure he could handle with magic or something, but he's actually afraid of Michael. 13. He's thoroughly convinced that Nick's death is a whole lot his fault, because of the incident in the closet with David. 14. He wants to go home now, back to Chicago, and just let the wizards chasing him do what they will, because he doesn't feel he's any good to anyone anyway. Oh, he'll fight like hell, but his heart won't be in it and he'd probably lose. 15. He doesn't know about the memorial service, but if he did, he wouldn't feel that he belongs there and he wouldn't be able to dredge up any 'happy' memories for it anyway. 16. He really thought he was doing well; thought his life was going to be different; thought he was going to be able to actually celebrate Christmas, especially since his father's around, but now he can't be arsed to even bother. 17. He hates holidays - all of them. 18. Right now, he couldn't come up with 5 things he likes, much less 20, hence the really nasty list. 19. He's 6'8" and skinny as a beanpole; can eat like a horse and hardly gain an ounce, but if he doesn't eat, he shrinks down to almost nothing; and the only disadvantage he's found to his height is the difficulties with having sex with considerably shorter people. 20. He's never told anyone this, but when he was fifteen, he tried to run away from Justin - his life got a whole lot worse after that.

[Harry is in a tremendous amount of pain and when the pain recedes enough that he can see and move, he realizes what's happened and things get worse.  By the time he's done, there isn't much left in the room <small>((this is Harry's room that's next to his old room, not the one he was sharing with Bethany across the hall))</small> that's not been broken into smaller pieces.  

Have we mentioned that Harry doesn't handle his emotions and anger well?  

When he's finished breaking things, he takes the few bits and pieces of his stuff that he'd moved to this room and carts them back to the 'cave'.  He tears the sign off and tosses it to the floor.  The door is closed and locked and Harry hasn't touched it since he stepped inside.

Bob is wisely remaining silent.]

[After the 'situation' in the closet, Harry finds Bethany and says they need to talk.]


"Hey," I say and push open the door to my room.  "There's something I need to talk to you about.  I'm not very good at this, but it seems to work out better for everyone else I know and I think you need to know about this as much as it's going to probably suck."

Now I need to breathe for a few minutes; get all my thoughts in order.
Testing some code... if I delete this... you know stuff didn't work and I'll do something else...

<lj-cut text="Candle... stuff">

I don't know when he did it, or exactly why, but the candle on the shelf in my room...

It's gone out now.

I don't know why this bothers me, but it does.  Partly because now it's dark in my room again, but also because it feels so final.  Like I've lost more than just an angst-riddled lover.  Like he doesn't want any part of me at all anymore - including my friendship.  Of course, I don't know if that's what he's done or not.  He didn't tell me he was doing it.

Know what, that's fine.  I spend more time in Bethany's room than mine anymore anyway.  So, we'll just change things up a little.  That will still be my room, but it'll be used more as my lab than where I live.  As long as that's all right with Bethany. (All else fails, I can move in with Adam; he'd love that.)


****** (several hours pass) ******


That's not entirely it.  I need to start over.  Clean slate, sort of.  Maybe this is actually a good thing; maybe it'll help strengthen my relationship with Bethany.  Maybe it'll help David too.

Maybe it just really bothers me that David didn't tell me he was going to take away my light.  There's not even a window in that room.  Hardly a light unless I fire up several candles.  It's so dark, so cold in there now.  Feels like my prison again.  I don't like it in there, not as a living space.  I want a new room now.  I don't know if I need one of my own or if it's all right to just slide into Bethany's, but I want a new room.  I can't sleep in that one anymore.  

Dammit.  I just need time to think again.  

I need to talk to Bethany - she's asleep. 

Shit.



</lj-cut>

Bethany, Since I can't talk to you, because I'm on this quest, I'll put my thoughts here. Adam misses you still. And he's concerned about you. One of the first things he asked me was if you were gonna be okay while we're gone. Then he wanted to play and make s'mores because he thinks that we're just going camping. I don't have the heart to tell him how dangerous this really is and that people could die. God, I miss you so much. It doesn't matter how you feel about me, I can't make myself stop loving you. Though, I know it'll kill me if you don't feel the same. I worked so hard... without realizing I was working, because I didn't want it, but I did - I worked so hard to figure it all out, only to learn that I'd actually known all along. That I was falling in love with you. I don't know how; I didn't know I was capable... and now, it's harder than ever, because you ran away from me and then, when I came back, you were gone. I didn't know what to think of that. And I had to take care of Adam - that was unexpected. I don't even know how I agreed to it, other than that I was just in complete shock and I saw the horrified look on Adam's face and I just couldn't tell him 'no'. Fucking hell, I miss you. But I don't know what I'm going to do if you tell me 'no'. David's making me crazy with trying to make everything like it was before - which just can't happen. It can't be. But this isn't about that. Or him. It's about you... and me... and I don't know what to do. I don't know what to say to you. Maybe because I don't know how you feel. Nick said you were glad to see me, but I don't know how to take that, since you just woke up and I figure almost anyone would have been a welcome sight. And I know we left you - we didn't mean to, but at least you're at Milliways instead of the hospital. We didn't mean to leave you. Adam was playing with the horses and I was trying to get him and bring him back into the bar before he got trekked off to Gwen's world and... suddenly we're both stuck in Gwen's world. Well, okay, not stuck, because I could get us back, I'd just end up, essentially, killing everyone else to do it. I don't really get along with most of these people, but I don't kill people. Not directly... and not anymore. Okay, this just rolled around to being about me again. Anyway, leaving was unintentional. We really need to talk. More than anything, I just need to know that you don't hate me. Because that? That just might kill me. I can handle quite a lot, but I don't think I could handle that. Promise me one thing, though - if it turns out that you do hate me, tell Adam the truth so that when you drag him away, he knows why. Do what you want to me, but don't lie to him. Losing you both will hurt me more than anything I've faced, but if Adam doesn't understand why, if he thinks it's because I don't care, when it's because of you, that would kill me. Like I said - do whatever you want to me, just don't lie to Adam about it. Please. Dammit, now my pages are all wet and if I'm not careful, they'll rip and why am I writing about the paper? I don't want you to hurt me again, but I'd prefer that, to seeing Adam hurt. I couldn't bear to watch him cry because he doesn't understand. And know this, if you do decide you hate me, I'm leaving Milliways for good. As much as it will hurt to leave, it would hurt more to stay and know that I couldn't have you. This is all a bunch of rambling that you'll probably never see, but I needed to get all of this stuff out of my head and this was the only way I knew how to do it. I do love you, Bethany and I miss you and I've run out of words... Harry
[Herein lies the adventures of a 5 1/2 year old mute boy in Chicago of 2005...]

Okay, so, shit. I don't know what the hell just happened, but most of it seemed bad, some of it seemed worse and NONE of it seemed at all good. What the fuck were we even fighting about? Then Nick-the-ever-helpful... I don't get him. But now, I'm back home and I have no fucking clue what I need to do now. "Harry! Oh, thank God." What the fuck is up with Bob? "What's wrong, Bob?" "Oh, man. Elaine was here - she looked pretty bad - she said someone had been 'talking' to her, trying to find me." "What? Why?" I mean, I know why people would want Bob, but why would people be searching for him? "Uh, since that little Darkhallow stunt, everyone has been trying to find me." Oh. "That's not good." "No, it's not." "Well, looks like you get to come along next time." "Next time what?" "Next time I go to Milliways." "Huh? I thought you hated it there." "Well, I did. But," I shrug, "things change." "Yeah? Then why are you here and not there? Hmmm? You finally decide you missed me? Hell, I couldn't believe you'd gone back the last time." I sigh. "No, missing you wasn't why I came back." I'm dumb. That was a bait. "Look, I just needed to get out for a bit. Things were... complicated." "Complicated how? You said the people there don't even like you, but that was months ago. You haven't talked to me in forever, so I have no idea what's going on with you." "Just... complicated. Look, Bob, I don't want to talk about it. I'm going upstairs. I'll get you before I go back though, okay?" Bob just makes a 'hrmph' sound at me and turns the skull around. Fine... whatever. ****** Pounding down the door won't actually get me over there faster. Though the sense of 'wizard in danger' lends a bit more urgency. I get the door open and Elaine nearly falls into my arms. She looks scared. I kick the door closed and throw up the wards, because if a Warden looks scared, there's probably a good reason for it. "Hey, you're okay. You're safe. They can't get you here." She gasps against my chest and nods vigorously. "Oh, they can. They can get in." "Not through my wards they can't." That seems to relax her a bit, not so that she lets go, but enough that she's not trembling. I feel her breathing even out and she sighs softly against my chest. "I'm sorry, Harry. I didn't know where else to go. I didn't even know if you'd be here." "It's okay." Funny, it actually is okay. I don't mind that she's here. In fact, I kind of like the company. Guess I got used to people being around. Don't feel as alone now. "Thanks, Harry." ****** I wake up and she's curled around me. Normally, this would be fine, but I'm sleeping on the couch, so this means it's rather difficult for me to do much beyond lay here and put my arms around her. She snuggles into me and amkes pleasant sounds... pleased sounds. Elain yawns and rolls her head back to look at me when she finally wakes. "Mmm. Sorry. Didn't want to be alone." "Figured. Next time, just ask me to share the bed." She smiles lazily and presses a kiss to the underside of my jaw. It feels nice, but I don't know what to make of it. I don't want to hurt her feelings, but I don't want to assume something that isn't there either. I just really miss the company... and sex. God, I miss sex. I miss Bethany. And I owe Adam a trip to the hospital to visit her too. Dammit. "What's on your mind, Harry?" Elaine asks. "Hmmm? Nothing. Just thinking." SHe sighs against me and hugs me and rubs her hand on my arm. "Who is she?" Wicked sixth sense she has. "Bethany." "You love her?" It's a question, but it's not. I nod. "So, what's wrong?" My turn to sigh. "She's in a coma." "Oh, Harry, I'm sorry." Suddenly, I'm in a bear hug. "Thanks." ******

...in little format. ******* The Getting Home... I figured I'd get visitors pretty soon after my return; however, the Jack and Jill of the White Council was not the welcome wagon I was expecting. And certainly not damn near the moment I arrived home. Home... that place that I hardly remember - small apartment that opens onto a yard that used to have grass, but is mostly dirt and rocks now, a few weeds and one shrub. No, that's what was there when I lived here before... before they sent me to that bar, that place... that I miss... hey, at least I never have to mow the lawn. "You're kidding, right?" I look from one to the other of them - Morgan and Elaine. "Elaine's a Warden now and you, The White Council, want my help to defeat some dark ritual?" I can't believe this shit. They want my help? How did they... nevermind; they're Council. The damned Council always seems to know where I am. Morgan shakes his head at me; he looks mroe surly than usual. "No, Dresden, we're not kidding." Elaine, calm, authoritative, steps forward. She's still as sexy as I remember her - even if she did try to turn me in. "Harry, you know we wouldn't be here if it wasn't important." I smirk. "Now, let me think... where have I heard that before?" I pause, long enough to garner a couple scowls. "Oh, right - the day before you imprisoned me at fucking Milliways!" I growl, stepping into her space. I'll give her credit for holding my gaze, though she takes a step back. "I should probably thank you though." I shrug. "I've never had so much really great sex in my life." Elaine blushes while Morgan just scowls. I have half a mind to ask him if that's permanent. "You were sent there for your own good, Dresden," Morgan feels the need to inform me. I snort. "Yes, because the Council was always looking out for me." Morgan snorts right back and waves a hand in frustration. "Forget it. We'll do it without you." And he turns and starts walking away. Elaine catches his arm. "Wait. Morgan, we need him." A glower from the hardened Warden. "Not if we can't trust him." "I'm not bailing the Council out of anything." I snarl. Essentially, the fucking Council can kiss my ass. Morgan glares at me over his shoulder. "What the fuck is your problem, Dresden?" Another snarl and I haul off and punch him across the jaw. "The Council turned it's back on me!" I growl through clenched teeth and hit him again. "On all of us!" Another hit. "Left us with Justin!" And one more for good measure. Morgan doesn't really like being hit - no one does - so it shouldn't surprise anyone that he turns and hits me back. "What are you talking about?" Seething now; anger so hot I could melt steel, I tackle him to the ground. Somewhere in my consciousness I can hear Elaine yelling for me to stop, but I tune her out. "Torture!" I yell at him and hit him in the face with each word: "Oppression! Molestation! Rape!" I'm so fucking angry, all the words just spit from my mouth. Before I hit him again, I see his face change. It changes from anger and hatred to complete shock. "What?" he asks in seeming disbelief. I scoff. "Like you didn't know!" Morgan shakes his head. "Believe me, if we had..." and there's a tinge of anger in his eyes - the seething, disgusted kind of anger... No, no - they knew... they had to. "No! The Council knew! People talked. They had to know. Kids said they told. They talked... and nothing..." I've been hitting him the whole time, but now, it's more violent as angry tears break free and slide down my face. I feel him grab my wrists, but still... try... "Harry," Morgan speaks in a low, comforting tone - which just makes me want to hit him again. But he said my name, my first name - he nevers does that. His voice is calm when he speaks again, "We didn't know. I'm sorry, Harry. I wish we had. We could have helped." More angry tears; they won't stop. "No one came. No one was there. We didn't know we could tell. We had all been sent there... from places we weren't wanted... didn't know... what were we supposed to do?" I want him to let me go. I'm exhausted. I need to sleep. He doesn't let go. In fact, he's... what the hell? "Harry," he whispers and pulls me down - down to rest against him, his arms around me. Morgan? Huh? "I wish there was something I could do." In any other situation, that one word would make all the difference - "I" - but today, "Fuck you, Morgan." Nothing from him; he just holds me - which is kind of fucked up, really. I mean, it's not sexual - perish the thought - by any means, but it's weird. "Let go of me, Morgan." "Let us help you." "We don't have time. The Darkhallow goes down tomorrow and they already have The Word." Morgan grumbles and rolls his eyes. "Not right now, you idiot." I snarl at him and push against his chest. "Let me up." He let's me go and I get to my feet. "Come on, we don't have all day." "Harry," Morgan calls to me, reaching for my arm, though a hand to his bleeding nose. I jerk away. "Don't touch me." He tries to glare at me from behind the hand on his nose. It's ineffective. "Dresden, are you going to let us help you?" I glare back - mine is actually scary. "Can we just deal with this Darkhallow problem first?" Morgan starts toward me again, but Elaine steps between us. "Morgan, if he doesn't want to help us, we can't force him." I wheel around to face her. "Why? Why didn't you say anything?" She turns on me, her face hard. "I dealt with my problems a long time ago. What was I going to tell them? It was over by then." "It's not over. It's never over," I snap. "You left, you... you left me. Everyone did." That seething anger is back. She sneers right back at me. "I asked you to come with me. To help us. You refused." "Because everyone betrayed me! Why the hell would I have wanted to help you?" She blinks. "Because we asked you. Though we'd been hurt, we asked you." Another snarl. "But that - leaving - that wouldn't have solved the problem! What about everyone after us? All the ones he would've hurt after we left?" She looks stunned a moment. "I don't know, Harry! We would have done something." I shake my head. "I don't have time for this. Are we fighting this Darkhallow or not?"
The Fight... Oh shit, when the fuck did he get involved? The Monster Hunter turns and snarls at me. I hope he doesn't think this shit is my fault. "Dresden! Little help!" Morgan and the Wardens are having a rough go with the zombies. Dammit. I fling a ribbon of flame - did I mention how good it is to have my power back? - and take out several ranks of the zombie battalion. We really need to stop it, not stand around watching. But I need a few things. "Harry, we could use some help," Elaine pants at me. "I know, but we have to stop the ritual too!" I call back and help with more of the zombies. Magical multitasking. "How?" Aww fuck, it's the Monster Hunter again. I glare at him. "Make Manilow over thre stop teaching the world to sing." I point toward the wizard in the circle who's yelling at the sky. "Again, how?" "Shutting him up would be a good start." "Fine." Michael turns and starts for the circle. "Michael, wait!" He doesn't stop - bastard. "Michael, if you go in there alone, the energy backlash could kill you!" "I'll take my chances." And he keeps walking. Shit. "Harry, can you rechannel the backlash?" Elain asks. I turn and I snap at her - almost barking, "I DON'T KNOW!" Dammit! I need just a minute to think, get my thoughts together. Elaine is... she looks pissed and she's just gonna have to be, because I don't have time. The fucking world is going to be launched into a long period of darkness and evil and I have about ninety seconds to figure out how to stop it. Even better if I can do it without killing anyone.
The Return...to Milliways... Dammit. I think I can still walk. It hurts like hell, but I can walk, though probably not far. My pseudo-arch-nemesis there is in much worse shape, despite the Warden healers working on him. Shit. "Move, just... go take care of the others; I'll make sure he's okay." Morgan glares at me. "And we're supposed to believe you?" I glare right back. "Is there anyone here who can help him?" Expanse of silence. "Didn't think so." I pick Michael up - no easy feat considering my own wounds and his weight - he's a lot bigger than I am - and start toward my apartment. I'm not going to my apartment, just in that direction. "Harry, where are you taking him?" I turn to her - Elaine; Morgan's right beside her, snarling almost. Of course, I help save the damned world and still get nothing. I just shake my head and turn to start away again. "Milliways," I call over my shoulder, then chant the incantation that opens the door. What? You didn't think I'd never looked the place up before, did you? The door opens and I step through...

Harry's a wizard, but there's more. He's also a very broken little boy, tortured, molested, full of pain. And from this broken boy, emerged an angry, sad, lonely man. He's not intrinsically evil - he wasn't born that way, he was raised that way. There is rage - at Justin, at what he did, at what he made Harry do; at Justin's other students who abandoned him because he learned to fend for himself; at the White Council for turning their backs on him and not stepping in when they knew what Justin was and what he was doing; at Elaine - (whom he knows, but never loved) - because she's helping the Council. There is, buried deep, the secret, the side he uses, but doesn't show - a part of why the Council sent him - manipulation. He can manipulate people into doing things. That's how Justin was killed in the battle against the vampires. Harry manipulated Justin into working his way further into the battle - used Justin's arrogance to force him to do stupid things - and it got him killed. The Council could never prove that Harry had done anything, but Harry knows he did it. And - the time he almost killed Michael (Gabriel) - only he wasn't actually there, he was working 'remotely' and controlling the demon; he almost killed Michael. And the time he nearly killed Elaine, who was helping some wizards from the White Council hunt vampires. That resulted in the death of one wizard - not directly Harry's doing, which is why he wasn't executed. He was sent to Milliways instead. There is also the tiny part (that grows larger with each passing day), buried way back, deep in the corner of his soul, that is beginning to care for Stephen and David and Adam and Bethany... maybe others. Harry would have - before - sooner admitted to having Justin killed than to having any kind of 'feelings' for anyone. Slowly, very very slowly, this is changing.

So, figure it's time to chat with Bob again. Wouldn't want him, or the White Council to think I'd given up on trying to get out of here or anything. I haven't. "Bob. Wake up, Bob. Need something." "Aww, Harry... wait. Harry? What the...? Where the hell have you been? The Council's been asking if you'd contacted me for weeks!" "Oh, I didn't know they cared." Heavy on the sarcasm. Really. Bunch of fuckers. "Of course they care, Harry. You're crucial to something-or-other that's gonna go down here soon. You know that." Wow, Bob's picked up the sarcasm a bit. Or he's sending me code. Sometimes I can't figure which. "Yeah. I know. Anything on that, by the way?" "Nah. Nothing worth mentioning, anyway." "Meaning: They don't have the first damned clue." "That's about the size of it, Boss. So, what'd ya need?" Oh, right, told him I needed something... uh... "Well, information, I guess." "About what?" "A potion." I'm pulling stuff out of my ass here, okay? There's a sigh from the other side of the mirror. "What kind of potion?" "Truth serum. Wanna find out if some bitch is lying to me or not." "Oh, well, I'm sure I can help with that. Here's what you do..." I write down the stuff he tells me - hey, it might actually come in handy some day. "Thanks, Bob." "Sure thing, Boss. Look, I'm beat, it's the middle of the night here... can I go back to sleep?" "Yeah, but only because I'm having a good day." "Later, Boss." I toss the towel back over the mirror and wander back out into my room to read... or something...

<lj-cut text="Harry's morning...">

So, yeah, I brought Adam up to stay with me last night, which is the scariest thing I've done since I've been here.  No, kids aren't scary, but the thought of what I could possibly do to one if I'm anything like the man who was the closest thing I knew to a father-figure.  I don't think I am, but I can't be sure.  

Anyway, when I woke up this morning, two things: first, Adam was curled around me like a monkey; and two, Bethany had come in at some point after we'd fallen asleep.  Not that I mind at all, but I usually wake up when people come into my room.  It's an instinct; a survival tactic.  

Must say, it was rather nice waking up, warm and not alone.  Just because I'd spent so much time cold and alone, doesn't mean that I'd gotten used to it, or even liked it.  I avoided people a lot, but oh fuck it... I'm not gonna sit here and just spout off all my problems.  Whatever, I'm over it.

And I'm staying in bed... it's warm here.

I walk up the stairs and into my room... fucking Gwen - put candles up.  I wave a hand and they all go out - all except the first one David lit earlier today.  That probably means something, but I'm too goddamned tired to care.

If I can manage it, I'm going to sleep.  I just can't take this shit anymore.  I give up.  Should've known there was no way it would work.  I don't want this head barman job anyway - don't want to be here at all.  This just makes it worse.  

Fuck it.  I'm going to bed.

I haven't done this in a while... Bob probably thinks I'm dead or something. I might look it actually. Whatever. I peel the drape off the mirror and wave my hand over it. "Bob. C'mon, Bob, I don't have all day." There's a yawn, then orange eyelights flicker up and Bob's peering back at me. "Hey, Boss... what the hell happened to you?" I glare. "No. Woah-ho... you look like you just went several rounds with one hell of a dominatrix. Was she good? Oooh, if only..." Still glaring. "Bob, I don't have time for this bullshit. I need to know how to find bits of organic material of something that's been dead for about five months." "Uh, dig up the body?" "Thank you. That would be a big help if I knew where the body was. However, I don't, so I'll need a bit more than that. Stop pissing me off." "Oh, all right. Gimme a minute." Bob's minute turned into ten or fifteen. Which, I kinda figured. "Bob," I growl, impatient. "Sorry, Boss. Had to really dig to find the info. All right, here's what you have to do..." He gives me this list of things I need and what to do... and yeah, I'm writing it all down, do I look that dense? Really. This is a one-shot gig, I can't risk doing it wrong. "And you're sure this'll work?" "Of course. Where do you think Justin got so much of his power? Teddy bears?" "Bob, you're a bastard." "Uh huh. So're you. What's your point?" "Good bye, Bob." I drape the mirror again and tuck the list into a pocket. I've made a copy, of course and tucked that away too - can't be too careful.

[Harry's Room]

So, yeah - just sitting here, with my one candle, reading this one book that I've read a dozen times, but I don't have anything new.

So, yeah, cold showers - they suck. Sure, I'm used to them, doesn't mean that I like them. They're cold. The human body doesn't like to be cold. The wizard Harry isn't all that keen on it either. I can think of much better things to coat my body with than ice cold water. Much nicer things to be pressed against my skin. A vampire... a stripper... him... And, dammit! How do I keep doing that? I mean, sure, he'd make a great pet, but more than that? Never. There's no chance I'd ever commit myself to anyone like that. Hell. Justin tried. All the time. But, the biggest problem with him - he was awful in bed. Stupid bastard. No wonder he had to chain people up - he was so bad, it was the only way he could get any. He's dead now. Big showdown with some Red Courts and the White Council. I didn't even have to do anything. Oh, sure, I was planning to take the fucker out on my own, but the Reds made sure I didn't have to. Of course, the bloody Council thought I was at least partially responsible for it. I think that's part of why I'm here. Oh, there's no chance I'm spilling everything about what sent me here. Gotta have some secrets. And now... now there's this guy. Says he gives a shit. I don't know if I can believe him. No one else has ever cared about what happened to me. Not Justin. Not Elaine. Surely not my godmother. I don't know about my parents - they both died when I was young. I just remember being on the street one day and slaving in Justin's lab, being berated by a talking skull the next. No one cared what happened to me. I know, I checked news reports and missing persons reports, even the backs of milk cartons. I even called the police once to find out if anyone had reported a small, lanky, brown-haired boy missing. Nothing. Not ever. So, I gave up. Gave up trying to figure out who I was and concentrated on who I would be. Justin helped with that. He wanted a prodigy, but he got 'the kid who had to work harder than everyone else just to get the basics'. Do I have to mention he hated that? After enough months of that shit - (ie: when I was old enough to look old enough for him to not be harassed - had told me that every time I failed to learn something after the first lesson, I'd have to suck him off - which, by the way, is damn near a fate worse than death. So, I would work my ass off to learn things, just so I wouldn't have to put my mouth anywhere near his dick. [Really, the man was foul. Expert wizard, but foul.] Enter why I can't give head for shit - a) didn't fuck up enough to have to learn to be any good at it and b) after that, no way in hell was I ever offering - to anybody.) - I got to where I was able to learn stuff pretty quick, because it was add-ons to the earlier stuff and it meant I didn't have to humiliate myself to be good at my work. Okay, so, how exactly did we get on that topic? Right - Justin. So, anyway, back to the guy who claims my life is worth his time. Him, him I don't get. At all. And not just because he likes someone that I can barely tolerate to be in the same room with, but, because I just don't understand how he works. Most people, I have a pretty good handle on from the start. But this guy, he confuses the hell out of me. On many levels. I mean, I understand that he asked for sex based solely on the fact that I opened my mouth and spoke to him, perhaps even amused him, but everything else? I mean, he talks to me. Just talks. Which baffles me. But what baffles me more is that he fucking compliments me. Granted, some of that was about my sexual performance, but some of it wasn't. I'm an absolute bastard and he's nice to me. Now do you see why he confuses the hell out of me? Oh, and there's not a chance in hell I'm ever telling anyone any of this. No one. Not letting that busybody of a vampire bite me either. You think I don't know why he does that? Bastard uses that the same way wizard use the soulgaze - to get a good look at what's inside someone - the stuff they don't really want you to see. So, yeah, no biting. That, and I've more than had my share of pain for a lifetime. Thank you. Now, do I go downstairs and tolerate the locals or stay up here forever? You know, think I'll stay up here. not really up for being around people just now.

Harry + bad mood + seriously unsatisfied = REALLY REALLY BAD NIGHT.

And you know... no one's gonna come up here and knock on my door and ask if I'm okay. If I punch a hole in the wall, there won't be a vampire around to make me feel better or to even offer I punch him instead. So, I won't put a hole in my wall. I'll just take my cold fucking shower and go the fuck to bed.
